title: Aspasia
summary: Aspasia of Miletus (/æˈspeɪʒ(i)ə, -ziə, -ʃə/;[1][2] Greek: Ἀσπασία Greek: [aspasíaː]; c. 470[3][4]–c. 400 BC)[3][5] was an influential metic woman in Classical-era Athens who, according to Plutarch, attracted the most prominent writers and thinkers of the time, including the philosopher Socrates, to her house, which became an intellectual centre in Athens. Socrates described her as a skilled teacher of rhetoric. She was the companion of the statesman Pericles, with whom she had a son, Pericles the Younger, but the full details of the couple's marital status are unknown. Aspasia is mentioned in the writings of Plato, Aristophanes, Xenophon, and others.
